posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.com: I've driven the Fiesta ST a few times, including around a little autocross course. Also driven the Focus ST and RS, several gens of GTI, Golf R, several WRXs, Mini Cooper S. The Fiesta was by far the most fun. The GTI is great if you want a comfy daily/highway car and there's a lot of power per dollar available aftermarket. The Fiesta is small, light, stiff, has short gears, and the right amount of power for my local fun roads.

>>26170212
For the people who haven't driven the other stages prior.
The rest of those stages are, with two exceptions, also some of the tougher gravel stages RBR has to offer. We'd ran a tarmac version of one of the Swiss stages, so you'd know what lack of margins of error you'd expect. The Diepflingen stages are that with a factor of ten.
I'd also recommend at least having a practice run on the Carvalho de Rei stages, those are stages with very nice flow, but with some brutal sectors where it is all too easy to crash off course.
This is one of the rallies you should count your lucky stars that it is on Reduced damage mode now, because you are going to need it for these stages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170899
Yeah, the final sector of Carvalho del Rei reverse is one of the most brutal gravel sections in RBR in my opinion. It's mostly due to the usual direction and sprint version being uphill, which is already tricky with a few nasty bumps, but it is only on the reverse stage you realize how steep that section really is. And having to brake hard downhill at full speed rarely ends well in RBR. It makes that downhill section very deceptive and treacherous even when aware how tricky it is. It's definitely one of the sections where you need to exercise utmost caution at every single bit, and it really doesn't let up until the finish line.
It's normal in most rallies to see most of the field either DNFing or racking up multiple CFHs on that stage whenever that stage is ran in it.

>>26173499
This
The newest racing game out right now is Unbound and it's literally a reskin of a reskin of a reskin of a game from 2014 which is just Burnout Paradise in the Battlefield 3 engine.
Once your PC runs all the games you enjoy playing you don't have to upgrade for years, there's no proprietary disk format or architecture change preventing you from playing the games you bought last gen.
If components do fail you can replace them. My OG Xbox is dead from old capacitors. My PSP's batteries have bulged. Vita needs to be cracked just to get on the internet. All my childhood pokeymans have been lost to the ether thanks to dead cmos batteries.
But on the PC I have access to literally every game on every platform ever conceived since the dawn of the computing age, direct access to all files and godlike control over the quality of my experience. There really is no comparison. If you really truly appreciate the vidya a PC is the only choice and the slightly higher buy in cost is completely justified by how infinitely useful the tool is.
That said I bought a Series X primarily because it lets me store and play throwaway stuff like Forza or COD that would otherwise take up 100 gb that are better utilized for shit like BeamNG and AC mods.

How do you convince anyone in their mid 20s to take their pickup truck off road? I have a friend with a OBS F350 crew cab 7.3 4x4 manual diesel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170736
solid front axle is strong and flexes well. except in a diesel.
diesels are fuckheavy and sink in mud and snow

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170736
The F350 uses radius control arms up front. They don't flex as well as three or four link but are more stable on the highway and better at handling heavy loads. From the factory most solid front axle pickup trucks are tuned for highway, not off road.

Also the idea that solid front axle is better for off road comes form its ability to easily be modified to flex with suspension upgrades. IFS can be very expensive and complicated to achieve the same flex you can easily get out of a solid axle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26174170
Reverse parking is an intelligence test. Incredibly simple, yet it works on multiple levels.
For one it tests if you have a concept of delayed reward. Reverse parking is slightly more difficult and time consuming than forward parking for a novice. Yet when you come to leave, driving forwards out of a space onto a busy street or parking lot is infinitely easier than backing out and being unable to see what's coming. The payoff is well worth it.
But that's not all
Reverse parking is easier than forward once you practice, but more difficult initially. So it is also a laziness test. Someone who gives no shits about what is better in the long run or improving themselves will always choose the lazy option of badly forward parking because it is "easier and quicker", and they will spend their entire life doing that.
For those that aren't filtered by the laziness and intelligence test it actually works out even better once you practice due to the way cars turn. While going forwards the rear end follows the front and cuts the corner trailing behind you. You have little control over this. So to forward park properly, you have to swing the front out wide (which you don't always have room for) so that the rear end can cut the corner and end up in the right place. Most forward parkers are too stupid to realise this, so they end up backing out and in again multiple times or they just leave the car at a stupid angle they initially pulled in at.
On the contrary, while going backwards your car becomes rear steering. By thinking ahead you can make very tight turns and still end up placing the rear of the car exactly where it needs to be then correcting the placement of the front of the car in the same motion

Tl;dr being able to rear-park is a retard test

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are a few reasons why backing into a parking space may be considered better than driving into a parking space head-on:

>Improved visibility:
When you reverse park, you have a better view of your surroundings because you are facing the opposite direction. This can make it easier to spot pedestrians, other vehicles, and other potential hazards.

>Easier exit:
When you reverse park, it is easier and quicker to exit the parking space because you are already facing the direction you need to go. This can be especially helpful if you are in a crowded or busy parking lot.

>Increased safety:
Reverse parking can also be safer because you are less likely to hit something while backing up than you are while driving forward. This is because you have a better view of what is behind you when you are backing up, and you can use your rearview and side mirrors to check for obstacles.

>Better control:
When you reverse park, you have better control over the vehicle because you are using the reverse gear. This can be especially helpful for drivers who are not comfortable maneuvering their vehicle in tight spaces.

"back pressure" is just an exhaust restriction, less you have the better. if you can scavenge the next pulse with the last one even better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26174258
Because it's not properly explained so people just repeat it wrong. Back pressure was required because fuel had lower octanes which allowed the gasses to reignite from the heat of the pipe, that's why loud bangs from car exhausts were common back then. It was a safety feature to have an exhaust system that expelled the gasses in a fast way so if there was an ignition it wouldn't be inside the exhaust system only at the end, increasing the life expectancy of your car

When 90 and above octanes became the norm the back pressure stopped being necessary, this means the width of the exhaust system is the actual important part of it to make the engine be efficient and that, as you can see, is not back pressure

What you're looking for is exhaust velocity and scavenging, smaller header diameter increases exhaust scavenging at lower RPM because of the higher exhaust velocities but starts to form more of a restriction once you get higher up in the RPM range, leading to less top-end power.

When you can no longer get parts in a week or so then you're hitting the limit, at least for a daily.

Had to sell an old car of mine that I had worked on for quite some time. The left drive shaft's boot had shattered and the grease fell out, didn't notice until it was way too late. Sold it to the first buyer.

Sometimes I wish I didn't sell it and just kept it and replaced the shaft. but, I'm seeing people beg in every forum known to man as to where they can find a decent used one, no one to my knowledge has actually managed to find one.

Depends on so many personal factors. One thing youre really buying is the engine. I think today the biggest factor is older cars might have an amazing engine, but theyre slow and get terrible mpg. As they get older little things will wear out, and it can be frustrating (again personal situations). If you need to budget your life forever you have to deal with it. If you make 100k and like to save, the convenience of buying something newer can easily make sense. There is also leasing if you desperately need reliability and dont know how to work on a car, but youre on a budget. I would be comfy buying a 1992 ls400 from the original owner that has full maintenance records and 200k miles on the car. I would not be comfortable buying a 5 year old impala with 100k from Shantalaquika. So it all depends. My oldest care is 1987, and it is somewhat reliable but you couldnt rely on it to get you to work year round.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26171716
>"open auto stipulation" is the biggest horse shit thing i've ever read

Depends on the bank's lending algo, in general the number of allowable open auto loans is based on DTI (debt to income ratio) but there's a lot of circumstances where the open auto (and other) stipulations can get throw a wrench in the mix. Computers are stupid and automated approvals fuck up all the time.

For example someone might take home 10k/mo and have two open auto loans where they are paying 500/mo each with no other debt obligations. Clearly they make enough to afford another car payment based on their DTI but if they've only had those two loans open for 6 months or something there's a shitload of banks that will deny them an approval based on their automated algo. In those cases the dealership finance rep has to call the bank rep and negotiate an approval on the phone.

>>26166270
Oh that's not hard actually.
Cadillac exemplified the size-era of luxury auto manufacturing, typically thought of as the period between WWII and 1980.
The post-war economic boon for Americans combined with rapidly scaling infrastructure came together to create the huge, beautiful, and powerful cars that dominated the US market in the 1960s and 1970s.
A whole host of factors relating to emissions, fuel consumption, and economic conditions all brought the size-era to an end, as small economical cars took hold in the American markets in the late 1970s.

1977 was the death of Cadillac, and GM's end to the size-era.

Post-war Cadillac is the Cadillac people remember, and their focus was on luxury and scale.
From 1945 to 1976, Cadillac made their cars bigger, better, faster, and that's all they did.
Add chrome, add cubes, add features, rinse and repeat for 30 years.
Auto-dimming headlamps, self-leveling suspension, power seats with memory settings, dual-reservoir brakes, automatic climate control, bulb-out indicators, Caddies were bad motherfuckers.
The cars themselves just kept getting bigger, with the Sedan de Ville breaking the 230" (19ft 2") mark, and the Series 75, sometimes mistakenly referred to as the Fleetwood, reaching a staggering 252" (21ft) in length.

(1/3)

The first production V8 in a vehicle was a Cadillac L-Head V8. Cadillac also produced the very first American V8 with a cross-plane crankshaft in 1924.
Post-war, Cadillac's OHV V8 design would become the basis for countless other GM engines.
Chevrolet small-block, big-block, and LS engines can all be traced back to the Cadillac OHV engine that earned them Motor Trend Car of The Year in 1949.
Conditions in the 1960s allowed for rapid increases in engine size and capacity.
From 1968 onward, 472 and 500 cubic inch engines become the norm for Cadillac, that's 7.7L - 8.2L.
In 1972 and 1973, the first automotive emissions regulations were put into place in the United States, thus beginning the malaise period of automotive design, and putting the first big nail in the Cadillac coffin.

In 1970, a Cadillac with the 500 cube V8 was putting out over 400 horsepower and over 550 ft lbs of torque, and in the 4,900lb de Ville could net you 12 miles per gallon.
By 1976, changes required to meet emissions brought the massive 8.2L V8 down to a pitiful 190 horsepower and only 360 ft lbs of torque, powering the now 5,400lb de Ville and getting only 8 miles per gallon.
During this time, the cars were still getting larger and more luxurious, with more features being added to distract from the steadily decreasing power and fuel economy.


(2/3)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26166434

A combination of increasing emissions standards, safety standards, and demands for fuel-economy from consumers who had now lived through the 1973 Gas Crisis, all pushed GM to bring an end to the size-era.
30 years of pushing bigger, faster, more luxurious vehicles had finally caught up with the reality of changing global economic conditions.
In 1977, GM began to downsize their vehicles, including the entire Cadillac line-up.
The 1977 DeVille and Fleetwood both featured a smaller 425 cubic inch V8 motor, they both rode on the shorter DeVille chassis.
They were shorter, narrower, and half a ton lighter than they had been before.

From 1977 to the re-birth of Cadillac in 1991, their vehicles continued to become smaller and simpler.
The lists of features stopped growing, as other automakers were catching up or passing them.
No longer was Cadillac home to GM's largest and most powerful engines.
No longer was Cadillac allowed to run rampant with design, the chrome and fins that once defined the appearance of the brand were slowly lost.

The first post-size-era Cadillac was the 1981 Cimarron, the first compact from the brand, and widely regarded as one of the worst vehicles in American automotive history.
Cadillac would continue to fail sideways through the 1980s, and it took the 1991 introduction of the Northstar to revitalize the brand and set the stage for Cadillac as it exists today.

(3/3)

If you'd like to learn more about the size-era, the malaise period, and the distinct global economic conditions that caused them, I'd recommend reading about the US dollar crisis, and the Bretton Woods system. Fun stuff, for white people anyway.

Not enough Cadillac love.

The Cadillac Series 62 "Eldorado" was introduced in 1953.
It was intended as a low production road-going version of the 1952 El Dorado "Golden Anniversary" concept car.
Only 532 were produced.

1967 - The Eighth Generation Eldorado
"It's like having a giant metal penis on wheels, and you get to show it to everyone and they just love it, they're impressed by it, they know your huge metal penis is magnificent and they just can't deny it when it's right there in front of them!"

Cadillac chooses the Eldorado as the name to carry them into the burgeoning personal luxury car market.
The segment was defined by large, powerful coupes designed with excess in mind, creating the cod-piece of the automotive world.
Cadillac redesigned the new 1967 Eldorado as a 2-door, front-engine, front-wheel drive coupe, sharing the E-Body platform with the Buick Riviera and new Oldsmobile Toronado.
At 18'5" in length and 4700lbs, the new Eldorado was a staggering coupe.
For perspective, the current Dodge Charger is 16'8", a shortbed single-cab F150 is 17'6".
The Eldorado featured a Cadillac 429 V8, putting 340 horsepower and 480 ft lbs of torque through the chain-driven Turbo-Hydramatic 425 transmission.
In 1968, that 429 was replaced with the 472 Cadillac V8, making 375 horsepower and 525 ft lbs of torque.
Finally, in 1970, the Eldorado was graced with the big-bad, the massive Cadillac 500.
Making a whopping 400 horsepower and 550ft lbs of torque, the 500 was exclusive to the Eldorado at its introduction.

The 9th generation Eldorado would follow, driving headlong into the malaise period, and bearing the compromises that served to end the size-era of luxury auto manufacturing.

Pictured is a magazine advertisement for the 1967 Cadillac Eldorado.

Remember, your fathers and grandfathers had better lives than you do.
Show your resentment this holiday season with the gift of a Cadillac magazine ad from eBay and a lengthy monologue about Nixon and/or Reagan.

Just try out a manual car and decide for yourself, if you have any friend who has one. You get more control, it's more direct, it's more fun. You can do it slow, you can do it fast, you can give yourself a little bit of oversteer by changing gear too rough in the corner on purpose, you can give yourself a nice bit of extra turn-in by heel-toeing and putting lower gear for extra engine braking, or you can just go nice and smooth and enjoy your own abilities to do that. Pulling off a nice and smooth rev-match is properly pleasant.

That being said, I've got no idea, I never drove a single automatic in my life because it's just not a thing in EU unless you have a very modern car. All of shitboxes in my family were always manual, my first car was manual, my miat was manual, my current car is manual. When people mention that manuals are bothersome in traffic, i always scratch my head because I've no idea what the problem is. Just use the clutch a lot, what's the big deal? Then again, I believe you guys that autos may be more comfy in those situations, it's just that I cannot imagine how the other side of the argument is like. But then again, regarding that, you're not enjoying cars in start-stop traffic anyway, so why not optimize your happiness for twisties where manual excels?

We don't know what car he has and we don't know how far he charges it or runs it down when at a track.
Model 3s on track range from about 600 Wh/mi to 1000 Wh/mi (33mpge to 56mpge) or 80 to 120 miles of range 100% to 0% for the 76kWh cars.
80-120 miles of range on a track is pretty typical for any unmodified car on a track. More than enough for track days.

EVs don't have the equivalent of a bolt in endurance fuel tank right now. Hydrogen fuel cells seem to be the first tech to solve that problem approved by certain race series rule books. But nobody is selling that kind of conversion system yet, and hydrogen at tracks right now is even more rare than fast charging at tracks.

posts.sub: Proposed new housing development threatens historic racetrack
posts.com:
MANATEE COUNTY, Fla. (WFLA) — A local developer aims to bring a new housing development to a 2,300-acre property east of Lakewood Ranch and just south of S.R. 64.

The project has been dubbed ‘Taylor Ranch’ and ahead of a vote that could move the proposal forward this week, some community members are speaking out in opposition.

The property sits adjacent to a big destination for the racing community, including Bradenton Motorsports Park and Freedom Factory.

Owner of Freedom Factory Cleetus McFarland told 8 On Your Side he fears the development, if approved, would end up shutting the racetracks down for good.

McFarland said the tracks have been operating off of S.R. 64 for 50 years and races draw large crowds and a whole lot of noise on a regular basis.

posts.name: Anonymous

Amazingly also in Manatee county I had some friends that lived in a quiet little neighborhood called Village Of The Arts (or VOTA) One day several years ago A man named Frank Tschida Said he would like to purchase an abandoned Packard dealership at the edge of the neighborhood and turn it into a brewery he did mention that he was going to put in a beer garden but that they would only host acoustic music and be done by 8:00 or 9:00 at night and even then only occasionally.

The people of VOTA agreed that this sounded like a fine idea and it was approved.

The very first night my friends had pictures falling off of their walls from the pounding base emanating from the breweries beer garden.
And it never stopped., Night after night it continued. The Bradenton police said they couldn't do anything because they had no ability to measure sound levels. This was not quite acoustic music. It was loud, it was amplified that it went on until one or two in the morning. Meanwhile, they were forced to wear noise canceling headsets to watch TV in their own bedroom.
I didn't have to take their word for it. I was there when this was going on on at least a few occasions. You had to shout to be heard in their kitchen while the music was playing.

Eventually the Bradenton police got sound meters but nothing really changed. They would issue warnings and then leave or issue small citations that the bar could easily afford.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26172768

2/2

Finally, it all came to a head after enough members of the community complained.

I was at the Bradenton City council meeting. One of the council members actually warned the assembled crowd that the other council members had already made up their mind and that it was a lost cause. He was only one of two that voted for regulations that would have limited how loud the music could be and when it had to stop.

The council decided that it was tired of young people going to St. Petersburg for live music and that the people from VOTA were just out of luck as the city was considering changing the entire area to an entertainment district. Again, all in the name of keeping people from crossing the bay into St. Petersburg.
My friends ended up selling their house still at a profit considering what they had paid for it and bought a much nicer house between Sarasota and Bradenton.

Manatee county is not one to let anything stand in the way of their financial progress. If they think the tax revenue from the houses will be more than the money they make off of the race track, then things don't look good for Cletus. For years, Manatee county has had a chip on its shoulder because Sarasota county is so much nicer and has a lot better tax base. Manatee county is determined to close that gap no matter what it takes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Unlike the consumers of public transit sodding up this board with nonsense, I owned a Maverick.

Got it at MSRP, only option was the EcoBoost.

Pros- interior design shows maybe things are trending better. It didn’t have a 14 mile long sloped dash covered in a million buttons. Anything you’d need to use was a button or knob, you could get by never touching the screen. Economical- I got 29 mpg in mixed driving around suburbia. Enough of a bed to do homeowner chores. It was quick enough to have fun, some suspension work would have made it a blast.

Why I sold it- I have two too many testicles. Auto stop-start is weird. It just didn’t have that solid feel of a body on frame truck. And it was a little too tight in the back for kids and kid stuff. Interior looked great, but easily scuffed and the plastic took scratches easily. And having a vehicle with embedded wireless functionality, including cellular reporting to the manufacturer on status and driving routine, just seemed too much.

Sold it, made money, bought a 2000 LX470.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173324
It's all about reducing the cost per mile on maintenance. Nobody making 7 years worth of payments on their 3-series wants to fork over $600 to service their transmission. So BMW (and others) call the fluid "lifetime" and "sealed transmission" to make people believe that the fluid doesn't need to be changed out, so then car manufacturers can say shit like "cheaper to maintain vs. XYZ" but the caveat is that "lifetime" usually means 80-100k miles before shit starts fucking up.

For example, the ZF6 automatic on BMW's 335i is "sealed" but shifts like dogshit at about 100k miles or so. ZF recommends something like 50k mile fluid changes but BMW says that same transmission has lifetime fluid and doesn't cost anything to maintain.

Pic related is on VW's website. I'm trashing BMW, but all manufacturers are guilty of this. I think the Toyota 4runner recommends trans fluid changes at 100k miles in the user manual if you drive the car hard or tow. I'm sure some trucks do too, I just haven't read it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173275
Yes its a totally stupid term, and I think it gives people the impression that you CAN'T service them, which is completely false.

I've owned multiple vehicles with "sealed" transmissions now, and have serviced all of them. Two were BMWs, one of which had the ZF 6HP, the other had a GM 6L45R in it. Both were very easy to service. Drain the pan (optionally remove pan for filter change), refill through the fill port with a pump. Easy as shit. Once the fluid starts to pour out the fill, just start the engine, then start pumping it in again. Use a scanner to watch transmission temp, once it hits the specified temp, and fluid is just dribbling out of the fill, plug it back up.

I've got two Fords now with 6R80s, its pretty similar, except they have this little dipstick you have to fiddlefuck with that is close to the exhaust which is obviously very hot at operating temps. Put on some gloves for these. Also, no drain plug. Otherwise, no big deal, pretty easy to service.

Meanwhile, I've got an old Chevy Express with a 4L80E in it. Absolutely fuck that transmission sideways with a pineapple. No drain plug, and while it has a dipstick, it is absolutely impossible to read. This cocksucker is 8 feet long, made of tinfoil, and feeding it back into the tube is like sticking a wet spaghetti noodle up a cat's ass, and half the time it binds up in the tube before getting back in all the way. The fluid level is almost impossible to see on the stick, and if you have added any fluid in the last 20 minutes, it will still be in the fucking tube, screwing up your reading. I wish it just had a fucking fill port.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Basically, I'm looking after my brother's car (Seat Mii, 55k miles) while he's off travelling, barely drive it myself but I said I'd become legal owner and let it sit in my drive. No sooner did he hand it over then the fucking thing develops this radiator leak (coolant runs to empty after a few hours driving - no external leaks, but wet seats and problems with damp/condensation/mould inside the car after leaving it for a week or two). I don't want to spend hundreds paying for a full repair on his car, but equally would feel bad if I got a repair done and then asked him to pay for it (as he's poor due to giving up his job and going travelling).

These products cost like £5-10 and promise a 'permanent' repair so it seems like that'd be a useful first strategy, but I'm seeing lots of mixed reviews online. On one hand they have loads of positive reviews and the manufacturers promise that they won't damage the system at all, on the other hand I've seen some forum posts that are adamant that you shouldn't use them because they clog up your system and cause long-term damage (the manufacturers explicitly deny this on their websites).

What do you think?

I would recommend going from point E to helsinki or turku, then taking the ferry to tallinn, then stockholm. otherwise the E-F-G is going to be dead boring. there's nothing in vaasa or umeå

otherwise the trip looks good. copenhagen is a great city, perhaps the best city in the nordic countries. be sure to visit freetown christiania. in norway, you want to go to bergen, then take the west coast to tromsø. I wouldn't continue much north as there is nothing to see there, really

so you would go from zürich to copenhagen, then to bergen, tromsø, hammerfest (if you really want to hit the north), inari, oulu, helsinki (our turku), tallinn and finally stockholm before heading home. or since now the baltics and poland are safer to drive you could also go from tallinn through poland back home

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173971
It's okay, but it's weak, regular oil changes (every 5k) gets them longer, and, even more importantly, ensuring proper cooling. Heat does crack the heads.
Mine has 250kkm, and with the recent overhaul it doesn't blow any smoke.

Fun fact: the RD28 is in essence a stroked RB26, with SOHC and a head built for Diesel. Big parts of it are originally designed for gasoline, and they were only reinforced just enough to not explode at Diesel-level compression.

An RB26DETT should fit directly (mounting points and bellhousing) though, so it's basically a lifted GTR. With 120hp.

No it's not, it's a heavily optimized van to be as efficient as possible while giving the operator as little strain as possible. My rebuild journey so far into this piece of shit

>car starts up, but need to switch the water pipe

>I'm fucking done with it at this point, drop it off at a reputable shop

The only reason I'm bothering to fix my OBXT (and why I spent $2300 on a written off LGT as a donor) is because I fell in love with it. It's basically a more practical WRX with more offroad credentials. It has sentimental value to me. It's an uncommon car anyway and even more uncommon in manual as well so it feels like a shame to get rid of it. I had looked for one for so long and it was a unicorn that showed up right in my backyard.
What I don't understand is why you bailed on the USDM 2.0 completely when the bolt snapped. Surely a machine shop would've been able to extract the snapped bolt for you. With the JDM you're really up shit creek. Hell you could've chucked the block with the bolt in it and bought a new one for what the shop is charging you to not fix your problem. If it were my money I'd stop pouring it into the JDM 2.0, sell it if you can, take the block to a shop and have them extract the bolt. You ain't the first person in history to ever snap a head bolt off in the block, they'll know what to do. Then proceed with the head gasket job as you were planning to do from the beginning.

posts.com: Can you air cool an engine by driving it around winter temps with the hood removed?

posts.com: How can a Hoosier such as myself renew an expired driver's license with no utility bills to use as proof of address?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156267
no, because the cylinders are well insulated from the exterior surface of the engine by the void cast into the engine which is called the "water jacket". cylinders in a water cooled engine lack the ability to transfer heat away unless in direct contact with water/coolant. also, the cylinder head depends on coolant passages as well, since it doesn't have enough surface area to lose heat via radiation or convection. keep in mind that the specific heat of water is much higher than that of air, meaning water can absorb and transfer heat much more efficiently than air. water cooling is considered better since you can easily maintain a controlled and uniform temperature throughout the engine, and it's easier to design a large powerful engine when you don't have to account for bulky external cooling fins.

an air cooled engine has the cylinder in close contact with the exterior of the engine, which is finned like a heat sink for air to be blown across. main advantage being simplicity, as there's no "cooling system" that can fail and leave you stranded (coolant leaks out, water pump belt breaks, etc) but the operating temperature of the engine is harder to control for different operating environments and loads, so the engine life is relatively shorter, and specific power output is relatively lower.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156267
ideally the radiators for water and oil cooling should have access to fresh air from outside of the engine bay, and dump their heat outside of the engine bay.
radiators can be remotely mounted .ie with longer tubes to position them more for better airflow. (don't ask me about pump head pressure tho lmao)
and proper use of ducting can prevent debris and insects from building up on the radiators.

other parts in the engine bay are air cooled and more confined in their access to fresh air, .eg fuel rails, fuse boxes, coil packs, alternator, battery
such parts are more dependant on the engine bays ambient temperature, but passive ventilation such as hood vents may be sufficient
but water and dust must be kept away from delicate components, so the vents should be placed with great care.

since you are driving in winter some of your engines parts may become too cold, or too wet. many older cars include muffs and baffles to deal with winter conditions.
and particularly in winter you must make sure that when you are stuck in traffic or driving up hill that your cars main ventilation fan is working,
I had an electric radiator fan whose thermostat had burnt out from being overworked, later replaced with a manual switch as a quick fix.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26156478
yeah but those trucks and your explorer were full of coolant being constantly circulated by the water pump thru the engine & heater core, even with the thermostat closed. if you couldn't get cabin heat at -10 your thermostat is stuck open, or heater core is blocked.

the outcome of driving with no coolant depends on the specific engine i suppose, but eventually it will get too hot to run and start pinging and knocking heavily. not uncommon to scuff pistons, blow head gaskets, warp/crack cylinder heads due to extremely localized overheating of pistons, bores and exhaust ports. note that peak combustion temperature in a gasoline engine can reach 4000F while the melting temperature of aluminum is only 1200F.

i remember riding a friends honda shadow for more than half an hour without realizing the cooling system was completely dry. ran fine until i slowed down for traffic, then it started pinging really bad and died, would just ping and kick back when trying to start. the temperature gauge stayed in the middle the whole time lol

>It's a really odd smell not related to anything in the car.
my money would be your evaporator drain is clogged and water is sitting in the evap pan and developing mold. find the drain hose and blow it out with compressed air then run some cleaner like simplegreen through the system to clean up the mold.
> do some car condensers for the A/C actually rumble harder than the engin
Your condensor is the radiator like thing on the front of the car and shouldnt make any noise, you're probably thinking of your compressor, the thing that spins attached to the engine. no, it is not normal for it to be vibrating, most likely it is failing and i would replace it before it gets metal shavings throughout your entire AC system, if it hasnt already

posts.com:
>>26168910
I can't really see the hose well in your pic, but get a hose that's made to be used either as fuel line or vacuum line, they sell it at your FLAPS. A regular rubber hose will get soft due to the oil.

Lean codes are often vacuum leaks of some sort. Get a propane torch (for plumbing), turn it on, but don't light it, and idle your car as you run it along all vacuum lines, pcv, intake, boost lines, gaskets, oil cap, dipstick tube, seals, etc. If you hit a spot where the engine speeds up, you've just found your leak.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170369
Check your fluid level and quality first, could just be low ATF. Also pull codes in case it's some sort of weird sensor problem. Check all fuses. Check your shift linkage, it's possible the transmission is ok the cable that pulls it in gear is just damaged or stretched.
If all else fails, just buy a new transmission and swap it. If you have a lift it's easy as crud, but it can be done with jackstands too. Ebay has used transmissions for your car for $500 delivered, your local junkyard would be half that. Give yourself a weekend and preferably find a friend to help with the lining up, but it can be done alone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26174775
>>26174796
The twisting motion is the key, you have to twist first that breaks the seal THEN pull out. Don't twist as you pull and don't pull first, twist then pull. You might need to use some hose clamp pliers or put some duct tape on vice grips if you dont have them to increase the grip for the twisting portion. Once it will twist, the pulling is the easy part.

Battery technology is one of the fastest accelerating products of our time. When you think of massive, quick advances in technology, the Industrial Revolution comes to mind and how we went from the first airplane to putting something in space in UNDER 40 YEARS

Recently, it seems as though technology has stopped advancing as quickly. Now that batteries are being used in cars, we will see that same expoential growth with battery technology. Modern cars will soon become like seeing an old 1960s carbureted muscle car. They're cool to look at but slow and inefficient as shit.

Phones have really been the only major battery powered devices in which companies have competed against eachother to have the smallest, longest lasting batteries but the vast majority of their R&D budget goes towards chip development and there are only 3 major worldwide competitors - Apple, Samsung, and Google.

Currently, every single major car manufacturer is pooling resources to develop electric vehicles and priority #1 with those vehicles is battery efficiency. As the tech further advances, so will efficiency and thus the amount of money it costs to produce these car batteries will drop exponentially. Electric motors are FAR more cheaply produced, reliable and simpler than a combustion engine.

I would say by 2040, we will see electric vehicles with 300 mile ranges being sold for what would be equivalent to $15,000 in today's money. For "super cars", performance will no longer be the benchmark - what will separate a "$100,000 sportscar" from a "$1,000,000 supercar" will be the technology, range, charge speed, and build materials.

Only 2 years behind right now, it was supposed to arrive at the end of 2020. So it won't be 3 till the end of next year, but I agree its not promising. It seems the main thing delaying it is Tesla thought there would be more progress at higher capacity batteries, but most of the R&D recently (even their own) has been put towards lower cost / safer / longer lifespan batteries to deal with the supply chain issues and keep up with the crazy demand for mainstream models. Which means they haven't put the investment into ramping up the higher density cells for high-end models. Which creates a problem for Tesla since they announced the Roadster as being 200kWh and 1000hp, while right now the best batteries available can do one or the other but not both at the same time.

Tesla may just be holding back waiting for solid state cells to come to market since those should be able to do both and bring a bunch of other advantages. Plus if they were to release a gel cell Roadster sooner, it might get BTFO by the new 911 that we know is going to use solid state tech.

>>26175221
Single motor cars do have only a single fixed gear ratio.
The dual motor cars have two different fixed gear ratios. Though they are as I said balanced to deliver most of their power at lower speeds.
The three motor cars have three different ratios. With one of them allowing for increased power delivery at higher speeds.
See how that works? 3 gear ratios, but all still fixed gear.

This is unlike the dual motor Taycan which has 3 gear ratios, with 2 being from a gearbox which shifts at about 70.
But it uses that extra gear to have a stronger launch, and it actually normally drives around in its top gear.

PTSD awareness edition, please don't trigger anyone

>For Classics made from 1980 or older, although exceptions are made for cars with a body style that started after 1980

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26170157
1. get it running and drive it as-is
Or are you asking how to get it running?
That's a lot more than 5 things

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170157
>>26170204
1. inspect oil level and check for water in oil
1a. if there's water you're fucked
2. find out if the engine turns by hand.
2a. if it doesn't, do 3 and 4 then come back in a day or two
3. remove and inspect spark plugs
4. put oil in plug holes
5. (re)install all but 1 plug
6. install battery
6a. watch for big spark when connecting battery
6b. look/listen/smell for burning when connecting battery
7. spin engine via starter motor
7a. listen to how engine is spinning (clunks, rattles, lunging)
7b. check oil pressure while cranking if possible
8. pull a spark plug and check spark
9. there won't be any spark
10. remove distributor cap and rotor
11. file points until you get spark back
12. reassemble rotor, cap, and put plug back
13. disconnect fuel line
14. bottle feed some gas down the carb
15. now it'll fire
16. feed some more gas into the float bowl
17. see if it'll idle
17a. if it doesn't, rebuild carb
18. plumb in alternate fuel tank
19. if it idles, make sure there's water in the radiator
19a. if there isn't, put water in and see where it leaks
19b. fix leaks
20. air up/replace tires
21. drive.

1. Clean it out, inspect status of rust deterioration.
2. Inspect for what's missing, is it complete
3. See if the steering and wheels turn, if it can be pushed around
4. Is the engine locked up? Does it spin freely? Check status of all fluids.
5. Disconnect fuel system, see if it'll fire off with starting fluid if all the above is good.
6. If it won't fire, start diagnosing ignition/electrical/spark system. Then you get into the nitty gritty of parts replacement/rebuilding

First thing I would do is probably put it on a lift and inspect damages, rust and etc.

Then pull out the engine and gearbox, along with anything else that's loose and can be replaced.

Either restore the engine if it's worth saving or just get some other engine and install it. Would probably cost the same amount in materials compared to just getting another used working one.

Best way to start with abandoned vehicles is to tear everything apart and inspect everything. At least if you're planning on driving it regurarily.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com: Hey fellas. This is a hard post. The Edsel pulled a Tesla during a 10 hour roadtrip. Total loss. I hit a big chunk of something that a truck in front of me kicked up. Rear tire blew out explosively and ripped the gas line off the tank that's beside it. Managed to correct the slide from the blowout and pulled over, but the sparks from the rim lit the open gas line. Nothing I could have done. Dragged my dog and cat out of the burning car, saved some gear, and sat back to watch all that hard work go up in flames. I'm fucking devastated. I'm prepared for the ridicule, but I figured I'd let the thread know that there won't be anymore edselposting, kek.

posts.name: 61 lincoln guy
posts.com:
>>26173884
god damn. worst case scenario, brutal.
why was a cat in ur car?

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26173889
Roadtripping home for the holidays. I was going to spend the entire week down south with the family. I took both my pets so I didn't have to get anyone to watch them while I was gone. The cat was in a carrier, so it made it easy to throw her out of the car.
Fire extinguisher I had in the car was not nearly enough to put out 10+ gallons of gas on fire. It killed it for a few seconds, but it flared right back up. When I knew it was a loss, I just started pulling everything out that I could. I know cars can be replaced, but it doesn't make it sting any less. Literally any other type of fire scenario, I could have handled, but the exploded tire sheared off the line connection at the tank and gas was everywhere. Those were brand fucking new Cokers too, it's not like they were old tires that were ready to blow. I'm pretty crushed.

>>26175153
>With the release of the 1988 model, the Fiero finally got the suspension setup the designers had wanted from the get-go. At a cost of $30 million dollars, a fully independent Lotus-designed suspension upgraded the 1988 Fiero's chassis, which finally let the car live up to its performance potential: shorter spindles, smaller scrub radius, reduction of the kingpin angle, longer A-arms, and a 28mm: anti-roll bar replaced the Chevette pieces at the nose. A new subframe with different attaching points, a three-link design, lower spring rates & a 22mm anti-roll bar did away with dated X-car components in the rear, and it received vented disk brakes and staggered wheels for improved handling balance. These improvements mean that the 1988 model year is the most sought after - and the rarest. The last Fiero rolled off the assembly line in Pontiac, MI on August 16, 1988 after only 6,848 Fiero GTs were produced for that model year.

>>26165418
It was so common in the early-mid '00s that you could rice a whole car out with one trip to Pep Boys. They had aluminum GT wings (usually comically undersized), knockoff Sparco seats, underglow, fake vents and scoops, hideous shift knobs, steering wheels, and clamp-on pedals, and various bodyside graphics sold rolled up, and if you had one of the really popular ricing platforms like an EG Civic or DC Integra you could even get application-specific stuff like lowering springs, clear taillights, and I think even bodykits at some locations. (Mine had a few on display but I'm not sure if you could actually buy them off the shelf or if it was just showing that you could special order them.)
Virtually everything was from this "APC" brand that's apparently been dead since '09, hard to even find pics of their shit anymore (and I wish I could come up with one of the ricer aisle at Pep's because it was hilarious) but this one will probably bring back some memories among my fellow 3x year old boomers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26165418
Yep, was definitely a thing. My dad took me to Sydney Show and Shine in 2004 and man it was wild. Everything was chrome and the place smelled like kebabs. I remember dad pointing out that most turbo kits fabbed on these cars didn't even run vacuum lines or oil/water feed - it was bolted on the day and all for show. If your first car was in the style of pic related in those days then you were king shit. I remember seeing chromed out Lancers, Civics, Skylines and Silvias everywhere with flame stickers and sound systems heavier than the car and being so jealous of how cool they were. This was also when you could pick up an R33 Skyline in turbo manual for less than $4k. It was a simpler time indeed.

>>26165418
I was a teenager and into import cars in the 90's. You know how in movies most of the important characters are attractive? Good-looking people exist in real life too, but you're unlikely to find such a concentration of beautiful people in real life as you do in Hollywood movies. It's kind of like that with the cars in those movies. Yes, you could see cars on the street like the ones in the movies, but it would be unusual to see so many that take it quite so far as the ones in the movies. For what it's worth, I consider that style to be more of a 90's thing than an early 00's thing, by the way. By the early 00's, it was already on the way out, and the dotcom crash / small recession around 2002 killed it in the US, imo. For a positive portrayal of that scene, visit your local library and see if they have old copies of Sports Compact Car magazine from the late 90's. For a more mainstream view, check out Bryan's Rice-boy Page. Note that the last update was about six months before "The Fast and the Furious" came out. It's still up at http://www.riceboypage.com/index.html

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26155512
International is the cheap fleet truck, they’re shitty. Everything is plastic and the smell of the plastic offgassing is so bad that you need to park with the windows open the first year of the truck’s life

Freightliner is probably #2 from the bottom. They’re solid company trucks, better than International, but nothing special. They might give you one piece of fake wood trim across the dash.

Kenworth is like Peterbilt Jr, the company doesn’t mind spending a couple extra bucks to have good lookin trucks on the road. Our Kenworths are way more comfy than Internationals of the same era.

Peterbilt is like Kenworth but even more of the Murrican Trucker. Tons of gauges with chrome rings around them, for owner-ops and companies that want to have lots of chrome on the road.

Western Star is a more rare one, all custom built trucks, like Peterbilt but more exclusive for the real super truckers.

Volvo is like if Freightliner cared about drivers. I love driving Volvos, lots of extra little touches, like Peterbilt but with a modern Yuro touch. Not sure if servicing them is so easy though.

Mack is a real small market share these days, not sure what happened to them. I saw like zero new Macks between 2000 and maybe 2015. They’re about on par with Kenworth, some chrome and not the cheapest looking, but they’re like 1% or less of trucks on the road so probably not great if you need service in the middle of the country.

>Litium mines
Lithium was waste at other mines until we started using it.

>Cobalt mines
Most EV batteries no longer use cobalt. Its primary use in transportation is still refining fossil fuels.

EV companies have way stricter supply chain management than fossil fuels which use slave labor extensively.

>Electricity powered by coal
A typical EV run entirely on coal emits about 240 grams of CO2 a mile.
A typical gas car emits about 270 grams of CO2 a mile.
Under 20% of the US grid input is from coal.
In the US charging on cheap base load electricity at night a typical EV gets about 58% of its energy from clean sources (Hydro, Nuclear).
Or about 100 grams a mile max. Some forms of clean energy like wind can have significant input over night and can reduce that further.


Since >>26165228 brings up natural gas
A typical EV run entirely on natural gas emits about 105 grams of CO2 a mile.
However this scenario is unlikely since natural gas is expensive and primarily used for peak power.

>Battery fires
Far rarer than fires in internal combustion cars.

>No way to recycle
Lithium ion battery recycling is a multi billion dollar a year business.
EV batteries aren't being recycled yet because none of them have gotten degraded to the point they need to be in bulk.
Even Leaf batteries are in secondary uses.

>Short product life
Most EV batteries today will last the life of the vehicle.

Sport 4s in 245/35 r18 on an 18x8.5 +45. I have a set of all seasons I regularly use and these fat ones are for *drive* drives. posts.name: Anonymous

>>26165936
that's kinda expensive for where I live but I don't know the market in your country
the facelift from 2006 to 2008 has a few improvements like a revised aux belt route that won't eat pulley and alternator bearings, exhaust manifold replaced under warranty with a cast one that doesn't crack, larger front brakes and a bunch of other little things, but both are solid cars.
the engine is solid, but use 0w30 oil only and service it regularly, I do mine every 5000km or twice yearly
fuel system is temperamental if you use aftermarket fuel filters, they're not rated for the same flow as OEM denso or Bosch
I've had mine for 5 years and the only faults I've had are worn out bushings, sticking rear brake pistons and a failing alternator

>>26135292
I used to do this as a high school job. We very rarely fucked with the coiling on anything but starters for big diesels. Not much actually goes wrong with them. Crack it open, replace or rebuild the solenoid, replace the drive if it’s shot, new bushings/bearings, fresh grease and they almost always work.

Weakest point is the solenoid contacts. Usually they’re the first thing to wear out.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26129723
I am currently chasing down a couple of issues on my newly acquired '97 F150.
>shifter
I've got a shift indicator that isn't indicating the correct gear and there's a squeaking/plasticy grinding noise when moving the shift lever down through the gears. So far I've replaced the shifter shaft bushings, shifter shaft clamps (the good ole boy I bought it from replaced on of the clamps with an ill-fitting strip of 20GA at some point so that cleaned up the shifter slop considerably), replaced the shifter and retaining pin along with adding a damper to further cut down on slop, blue Loctite'd all the fasteners in the shifter mechanism and torqued to spec, and I've checked the PRNDL mechanism to make sure it is functioning correctly. All of this has improved the feel of the shifter considerably, but no dice on the incorrect indicator and squeaky noise. Through process of elimination I am now convinced that the shift cable needs to be adjusted or replaced. I can watch the mechanism move from the floor and there is no slop. The noise seems to come from close to the firewall where the cable is. Like it is binding up or something.
>heater
I have no heat. I replaced the thermostat and in doing so realized the coolant system badly needs flushed. There's no air in the system so far as I can tell. The vents are blowing cold air so I narrowed the problem down to either a faulty blend knob, blend door actuator, or blend door. Today I removed the blend actuator to test functionality and further narrow down the problem. It functioned when turning the knob so the knob and actuator both work. Around the key that the actuator turns there is black plastic debris which I believe indicates a broken blend door. Tomorrow I am going to be cutting through the dash and plenum behind the glovebox and replacing the door. My hope is that between a coolant system flush, a heater core backflush, a new blend door actuator, and a new blend door heat to the cab can be restored.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26150528
I'm the guy that recc'd the chief. Before buying another tool you should make sure your compressor isn't getting cucked by 1/4" fittings and the shitty regulator. Highly recommend replacing all fittings and couplers with 3/8 ends with 1/4 npt threads and a 3/8 regulator. Make sure your hose is 3/8 too. No reason to go to 1/2 as it is too big for not that much gain.
Here's a good kit to get you started - https://a.co/d/bMkscuu
Also TTC video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KBQpaUBMmGw
Whatever you do, DON'T USE MILTON FITTINGS THEY FUCKING SUCK.

>>26155495
Some shit is easier on certain cars, some shit is harder. Inline engine only has one bank of cylinders so easier for headgaskets and stuff, but an I-6 could have stuff buried behind the firewall. Transverse engines mean you have to go in from the wheel well to do lots of the accessories and belt.

Something like an H6 Subaru with AWD sounds terrible to work on. Pickups and SUVs with V6’s and mid-full size sedans and crossovers or small SUVs with I4’s are both pretty easy for most stuff. But it totally depends on the job and the car because there companies don’t really think about ease of service when building the cars.

>>26157327

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26130254
I know I'm more than a week late to be updating this blog. But I managed to remove the old throttle cables with a combination of ring spanners, poking utensils and what girls refer to as 'magic hands'. My original plan to just replace the internal cable was foiled by the damaged English (oxford) and their refusal to include any of the cable ends that LITERALLY EVERY SINGLE JAPANESE BIKE USES in their "universal throttle cable kit". Luckily I'm God's favourite NPC so the go to bike bits shop had two (almost) universal throttle cable kits that ( were Japanese and) they sold for the price of one because I was wearing overalls and told them I ride a tiny Honda. I say 'almost universal because while my throttle housing had one M8×1.25 thread that fitted perfectly the throttle return is a M10× 1.25 thread, I figured out I could just drill and tap the end of the old cable. However the only way to buy a M10×1.25 tap on a Sunday is as part of a 40 piece tap and die set at any given hardware store.
But after all of this and some more 'Magic hands' I have a fully functioning bike with zero throttle slack. Those "universal" cables were a mm or two short, so if you as much as breathe on the throttle it revs to 6k. There's no excess tension on the cable it's somehow perfectly to length. And it's great, she feels more responsive than ever, in fact it's soo much better I've almost stopped complaining about the final drive ratio being too short.
Anyway good luck with your oil changes or whatever.

Not that anon, but you would want to check the ground strap between the block and the frame and the ground cable between the frame and the battery. >>26161880
I helped a friend stick an LS into his 95, you can actually very easily convert a DBW to DBC - you need to
>1: Add in the bosses into the intake manifold for the throttle cable bracket OR get a DBC intake. You can steal the nutserts from a junkyard truck and then stick them into your DBW intake which is what we did.
>2: Get a DBC throttle body. If you use a DBW intake manifold, remove the PCV fitting from it and plug the hole.
>3: Run the ISV and TPS wires to the correct pins in the ECU as you would a DBC - you need to get creative with I think 2 of the ground pins - we just used another ground pin that was unused in the ECU that did the same thing.
>4: Tune the ECU such that ETC is disabled (literally 1 bit in the tune haha)
>5: Winrar
As I understand it the DBW ECUs (P59) are preferible to the DBC (P01?) since they support greater tuning options and flex fuel support, in our case we simply used the DBW setup since the 5.3 we used came from an 04 avalanche and it was all included with the junkyard engine (fucking $200!)
We still need to tune out the auto trans code since he's running an NV4500, but it seems to be working for him so far.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26162695
Oh yeah I wanted to add the early chevy DBW is hardly a modern interpretation of DBW at all - the throttle and gas pedal talk through the throttle control module with the ECU also talking to it to limit throttle angle - the ECU itself acts very much like a DBC in that sense, only telling the throttle control module things like to limit torque when going too fast/limiter/transmission protection etc. It's not like modern DBW where the entire pedal angle->torque request->add in loss torque->engine load->manifold pressure->throttle angle process is done in the ECU and needs to all work correctly. That's why you can simply tune out DBW on your junkyard LS

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26162716
You need to hook up a scan tool and find out which cylinder(s) are misfiring. If it's just one or two, swap those plugs and coils (or wires if older car) with another cylinder. If the misfire moves to the cylinder you swapped with you know it's either your coil or plugs and you can swap those to narrow it down. If the misfire doesn't move, it's either your harness or a mechanical problem with the cylinder and you can troubleshoot from there.

>>26163519
A 15 minute drive won't be a problem. I wouldn't drive 100 miles that way as the excess fuel could damage your cat, but 15 minutes won't hurt anything

>>26164907
ok, spray all the spark plug wires down with water, run the car in the dark. does the misfire get worse when wet? do you see little spark flashes from the wires? if so definitely bad wires. also inspect your spark plugs, if one or more is more fouled or if there are carbon tracks that indicates a problem specifically in that cylinder or with that plug.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26162716
>>26164911
>Since I am able to smell unburnt gas out of the exhaust, would I be able to rule out an injector problem?
and not necessarily, a leaking injector will overfuel the cylinder causing it to misfire and stinking up the exhaust. the typical way to check for this is run your engine with a fuel press gauge attached. does the pressure drop rapidly after you switch it off? if so probable stuck injector.

NV3500 < All

"I don't do burnouts, I'm not a faggot, I'm not a hooligan, I don't abuse my shit, blah blah nigger dribble nigger dribble"

The NV4500 in the 3/4 trucks was far, far stronger, and is the appropriate choice for a 4x4 GMT400.
You can fit one into your 5.7l 1500 if you feel like it, fuckin' go for it, no downsides in my opinion if it's a 4x4.

If you're 2WD, I wouldn't worry about it, your feet are the killer at that point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26172339
Varies.
KO2s come in multiple formulations, your specific size of tire, vehicle weight, weight distribution, choice of wheels, and balance ALL affect tire noise!

Basically, you don't know until you know, and the same tires can surprise you from one vehicle to the next.

KO2s have a reputation for highway noise, but noise quality matters too.
When I had 'em on my 97 K1500, they were plenty noisy on the highway, but far less annoying than Discoverer AT3s on the same truck.
Similar noise level, but less obnoxious sound.

My boss has a newer Yukon on Michelin LTX, and I was impressed at how quiet they are.
On my K1500, fucking obnoxious between 45 and 55, so they're infuriating around town but silent on the highway.

Don't be afraid to bite the bullet and try some shit!
The big generics like Discount Tire won't hesitate to let you return tires if you find 'em obnoxious.
They may not be shit-hot on giving you your money back, but they won't complain one bit if you want to try a different tire.
That's exactly what I did with those Michelins (at a Ford dealer of all things, they had good prices), went back to a set of ATPs that will do just fine for now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26175082
They're getting popular because they're cockroaches and I mean that in the best way. Current record is 770k miles before being retired to a museum, many being driven daily with 500k miles on them. The frame is galvanized, the body is fiber reinforced plastic, so there's nothing to really rust or corrode unless you daily it in heavy salted snow. So, as Boomers age out of being able to drive them, there's a glut of C4-C7 Corvettes entering the used market and people that need truggs or family haulers can't use them, and of course fatty fats aren't in the physical shape to get into them. Young people often would have to pay a fortune in insurance due to the power, so there's just tons in amazing shape sitting around because people only buy them as 2nd or 3rd cars.

They're amazing, for the most part simple and reliable as long as you don't buy an abused one, and for 99% of problems there is a complete write up written by some Boomer 10-20 years ago on Corvette Forums to tell you everything you need to know. Compared to modern cars it's like working on a go kart. Just replace the seats and shift knob ASAP because both of those parts are shit stock. Corbeau A4s and a Delrin knob from eBay and you're set. It really doesn't even need power mods unless you plan to run drag radials, you can pretty much spin up to the legal highway speed limit as it is.

The only thing that starts or stops my engine are my fingers on the keys. Same goes for any other nanny-tech bullshittery.
I don't fucking need a rain sensor for the windshield wipers because I can see if it's raining. I don't need no headlight automatic because I decide when it's too dark for me to see . I don't want fucking lane departure warning because I'm attentive a when I'm driving. I don't fucking text or watch movies on my fucking 25 inch head unit while I'm driving a car. I don't need fucking touch screens because I got tacticle senses so I don't have to take my eyes off the road. I don't need any motherfucking connectivity because it's a car not a fucking smartphone. I don't need my car to fucking beep while I'm reversing and I sure as fuck don't need to look at a screen while doing it because I know how to reverse using mirrors! I don't need a 36 zone A/C sensor automatic yabbadabbadoo because the inside of my truck is smaller than my fuckingbathroom. I just need a fucking rotary switch to choose between hot and cold. I don't want my vehicle to be a fucking subscription service and I sure as fuck don't want my car to deliver telemetry data. I don't want two dozen air bags and other safety features because I don't drive like a fucking moron. I don't wanna save the environment with electric bullshittery. If modern people tell me something is good, I will probably buy the complete opposite just to spite them. I don't need my fucking car to tell me I had an accident or call a fucking ambulance. I will never buy a car where the connection between the pedals and their respective systems is not mechanical. I will never buy a car where the shifter is anything but a mechanically connectet lever.
FUCK all that modern bullshit. Give me a proper vehicle that's built to last. I don't need a fucking smartphone slash electric wheelchair.

>>26164993
ABS increases stopping distances on low traction surfaces like gravel or snow as the wheels locking up tend to dig in and create more grip. ABS stops this from happening.
you also have 'risk compensation' which is the theory that as the level of risk in an environment decreases, the more risk a person is willing to take. in the case of cars with all their electrical safety nannies, naerly all drivers of these will simply rely on ABS to do threshold/cadence braking for them without much further thought. They're also more likely to tailgate and drive recklessly since they figure that the vehicle will protect them from their fuckups, everyone else be damned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How do you guys center stickers? Like if I want to center one on my rear windshield, any tricks/tips?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164256
Use a piece of cord*. upper left corner to lower right corner. Mark the approximate center with a liquid chalk pen or something else thats easily removable.
Repeat between upper right corner to lower left corner. X now marks the exact center of your windshield.
*Cord because modern windshields aren't flat surfaces. Cord follows the form.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164262
After that you measure height and width of your sticker. Divide both values by 2 and you got the center of your stigger too
For example:
Sticker width is 10 inches then 5 inches is the center.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164262
Alternatively you can use masking tape instead of cord. Either way: Don't get distracted by the fact you won't see a straight line. That's due to the mentioned curvature of the windshield.

posts.com:
>>26164262

>>26171322
Cars in south east Asia (or atleast Thailand and Bali, the only two places ive been) are typically weird de-spec models of really normal cars like Toyota Fortuner, hiace, Ford everest, mitsu Pajero sport etc. With manual trans and lower emissions level engines. But what's really fucking cool about them is they dont even have heaters. The circular dial that would normally be red on one side and blue on the other as a "temp blend" dial is just blue all the way round as a "how cold do you want it?" Dial. And the "vent position" dial only has two positions - I think they are face + feet vent. So you've got the same big dial that in the western model would have like 6 positions on it, but only with two positions at opposite ends of the dial.

Shits crazy. And they drive quite weird too. Take off in 3rd gear, ride the clutch like fuck and as soon as they have fully released the clutch change up to 5th. Because revving over 1000rpm is considered wasteful driving. I assume the cost of replacing a clutch is very cheap for them because their labor is probably cents per hour and the clutch kit is an OE one snuck out the back door of the factory. Both Bali and Thailand are really cool places to travel as an /o/tist. Definitely recommend it.

Nissan has bungled its exit from the FIA World Endurance championship as badly as it handled competing in the fiercely competitive sports cars series.

Approximately 40 employees at the Indianapolis-based LMP1 program were notified by e-mail the program had been cancelled Tuesday morning, yet with many of the staffers on vacation for the holidays and away from work e-mail, news of the firing, for some, came from a press release the Japanese brand decided to post in its global newsroom. Those who did turn up for work Tuesday morning were barred access to the building, and senior team officials, who were also caught by surprise, stepped in to call and inform (or confirm) the sudden dismissals for all who worked at the facility.

Nissan's cancelation of the troubled program, just days before Christmas, is the latest chapter in what has been a truly tumultuous journey from concept to race.

Road & Track was present for the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO's debut on Dec. 19, 2014, at Circuit of The Americas, where the radical, front-engine, front-wheel-drive prototype suffered through a troubled introduction that made only modest gains over the next 368 days until the program's termination. https://www.roadandtrack.com/motorsports/news/a27710/nissan-fired-its-lmp1-employees-over-e-mail/

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26075559
Pretty much..
“Behind the engine and beneath the cockpit is a kinetic energy recovery system using two flywheels developed by Torotrak. The flywheels gain energy from the use of the front brakes then discharges that energy back to the front wheels via a driveshaft running over the top of the combustion engine. The flywheels can also output power to a secondary driveshaft which is connected to a limited-slip differential at the rear of the car which feeds epicyclic gearboxes located in each rear wheel hub, allowing the GT-R to be all-wheel drive if necessary.”

Sound complicated? It should, because it is.

Additionally, while the engine is in front of the driver, it’s also behind the centerline of the front wheels, so it’s more of a front-mid layout. As Bowlby explained in an interview with Racecar Engineering:

“The front tyres on the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO are bigger than the rear tyres – 14 inch wide front vs. 9 inch rear. This is due to the way that mass is distributed in the car. We have moved the weight bias forwards to give us traction for the front-engined, front-wheel drive. We’ve also moved the aero forwards so we’ve moved the capacity of the tyres forward to match the weight distribution. So the aero centre of pressure, the mass centre of gravity and the tyre capacity are all in harmony and that means we have bigger tyres at the front than the rear”

posts.com:
>>26068883
Mitsubishi Motors completely abandoned RWD cars with the exception of the Starion in the 1980s. This would be one of the many decisions that would bleed the brand over the next few decades.
When the big three of Japan decided to come out with their bespoke luxury brands, Mitsubishi decided there was no need for this despite having basically no clout in the American market, they made fleet and commuter vehicles. This combined with the pathetic 3.0 V6 meant the gussies up Galant known as the Sigma was a failure.
They also gradually fucked up their sports car lineup in the states as well. The DSM cars, Chrysler's FWD sports cars, and the captive import Starion (Chrysler Conquest), occupied slightly varying price levels but were essentially in competition with each other in the same showrooms.
The GTO/3000GT used a twin-turbo version of the 6G72 3.0 V6 in the highest trims. We know now that even this engine struggled to power the AWD system of the over 3500 lb car which wasn't helped by the two turbochargers. What's stranger is that the 6G74 3.5 V6 was dropped in multiple Mitsubishi vehicles, SUVs and sedans, and was able to approach the twin-turbo 6G72 in power in NA form.
During the height of the Fast and Furious tuner hype, Mitsubishi cut corners and made the third generation Eclipse FWD only, but let you have a V6.
The company would spend the 2000s and 2010s producing shitty commuter cars for the states, the market they invested so much into entering through the Chrysler partnership. By the 2010s they were essentially a second class Jap brand like Suzuki and Isuzu.

People don't understand how much of a shithole USSR was and Russia is.
In the USSR when you got married the state gave you a car for your honeymoon.
It was just for the honeymoon. When the honeymoon was over they took the car back.
My Russian high-school teacher was a translator for the Russian vice president (this was like '93 or something).
He showed him a Walmart and the VP thought it was propaganda bullshit, that the store was filled with items and people shopping just for him to see.
When my teacher showed him my school he didn't understand why there were so many cars. When he was told they were the students he refused to believe that kids had their own cars.

Russians were content with the Lada because just owning a car was an amazing feat in life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26167090
>but that's RPM draining the battery range.
Electric motors don't necessarily use more energy the faster they spin the way a gas engine does. They still only need to output the power required to spin at the desired speed.
Even with a two speed gearbox shifting at 70, you're still going to use significantly more energy over than point because it takes more power to push through the air at speed.

Multiple gear ratios on EVs are more about the ability to continue power delivery at higher speeds rather than anything to do with extending range.
A Tesla at 200mph isn't going to use significantly less energy just because it has a 2nd or even 3rd gear ratio, the Model S Plaid in fact has that many ratios available, it just achieves them without a traditional gear box.

The problem is that today you have real trouble packing more than 30kWh into a car not designed from the ground up as an EV, and if you want it to be a PHEV with a gas range extender and a reasonably sized fuel tank you're going to have trouble getting more than 15kWh.

>Id say the only problems with EVs today is the charging station
After owning an EV daily for a few years, Tesla's charging stations are actually great. 250kW is just fine for a 4 mile a kWh car to top up a decent amount of range on a day trip in just a little bit longer than it would take to put gas in, and 150kW charging while getting a meal on a long trip is super comfy, better than getting gas.
Only issue is there needs to be stations about every 50 miles, and right now they're every 100 or 150 miles. So much of the current slow charging times is just not being able to hit chargers at low states of charge and needing to top up in the top half of the battery pack.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173195
It has the n52, its a nearly bulletproof engine anon. A little leaky but that can be fixed with a valve cover gasket, vanos seals, and maybe an oil pan gasket if you're unlucky. I treat this engine like I stole it every day and its happy.
It has 100k so you will want to replace the water pump, thermostat, and maybe a hose or 2. Get a water pump kit - $600 or so. This is not a fun job, but you wont have to do it again for a long time.
2007 got a slightly updated engine, valve cover gasket is plastic instead of magnesium so they can crack. They are cheap though and pretty much only crack when the gasket is ready to go anyway. You can get a gasket+cover for around $200.
Being a 5 series, I assume its automatic - but it wont be SMG so really no concern there. If you're mechanically inclined, I'd buy it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26173195
replace the fucking belts, for some god awful reason when a bmw i6 snaps a belt it gets pushed into the front main seal and sometimes makes it into the oil pan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173315
It’s the tensioner pulley. Check that the belt is riding fully on the pulley. If it is past the edge even slightly then replace the tensioner and it’s mounting bolts immediately

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173315
>for some god awful reason when a bmw i6 snaps a belt it gets pushed into the front main seal and sometimes makes it into the oil pan.
lamo, is that what your mechanic told you? holy shit this board is funny.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173308
Also listen to this >>26173315. Replace the accessory belt if there is any sign of oil leaks after fixing the leak. Lots of engines will do this if they lose a belt, but the reason BMW is somewhat famous for this is due to the vanos seals. They are right in front of the belt, and they can start pissing oil right on it. You'd have to be a braindead retard who doesn't open their car hood ever for this to happen - it takes months of oil leaking for the belt to become oily enough to fall off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173333
You're retarded, it's a common issue. The tensioner bends inward when the spring wears out and directs the belt toward the engine. it's so bad they make seal guards to prevent main seal damage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173333
>a belt spinning around a shaft at 4k+ RPM can't wear down another piece of rubber
Holy shit you are dumb

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173349
>>26173350
how does the belt make it into the oil pan tho??

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173357
it gets pushed through the hole where the main seal used to be, then you have to drop the oil pan to clean bits of shredded belt out of the oil pickup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173363
>it gets pushed through the hole where the main seal used to be, then you have to drop the oil pan to clean bits of shredded belt out of the oil pickup.
okay

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26173357
It wears down the seal enough to break down and the belt gets pulled in between the pulley and crank. Imagine if the spot in my pic related lost 50% of the thickness due to a belt wearing on it. It will create the perfect width to fit the belt in the gap and that belt will get sucked in. The force is able to move the seal out of the way enough to force the belt through.
